content: OK, I have updated the spreadsheet and put in my proposed milestones and other parts of my proposed plan (e.g., a public blog posting schedule).
Please take a look at the "Milestones" tab of the tracking spreadsheet

The key part of the plan is

  • April 1: All features must have an approved RFC or other decision to be included
  • May 1: All features must be implemented
  • June 1: All features must be documented (migration guide etc written)
Ah, you moved the acceptence deadline again. Now it's back at exactly what i proposed in december. So yeah, lgtm.
What's the target date for the 2021 edition?
Also: "All features must be implemented" -- does that mean some version must exist on nightly, or we intend for it to be stable?

The one item I'm rather nervous about is that according to the tracking doc we are considering reserving a new keyword with only five weeks left until the deadline, with no lang liaison or RFC proposed. In the aftermath of the 2018 edition we all seemed to agree that we pushed too many things to right before the deadline, and we should want to prevent a re-run of this by starting efforts like these well in advance.
(I initially suggested about 12 months of runway for changes like these so we didn't have to rush, which I believe at the time @nikomatsakis replied to that that should probably be even more.)
to pick a date, Oct 21 as an initial date would let us slip a release (to Dec 2) if we had to.
@Lokathor would that be Rust 1.56, with a possible slip to Rust 1.57?
uh, maybe? my google calendar is set up to remind me of the days but the event series doesn't show which release number.
but those are the last two releases of 2021, so giving ourselves the possibility to slip once means we need to pick Oct21
[deleted]
@Yoshua Wuyts the dates in the spreadsheet
what new keyword are you referring to?
oh, perhaps "reserve yeet as a keyword"?
I would personally assume that is not going to happen, as we will not have an accepted RFC by April 1
(or other formal decision)
however, @Jane Lusby may have an opinion?
yea, I'm not working on this

it was an idea i was throwing around but the argument that people legitimately want to use this word as an identifier sway'ed me that it wasn't worth reserving this keyword in case it ends up being useful
or even just as a joke
@nikomatsakis yeah that was the one I was referring to

Hopefully we'll get the k#ident and thus won't need to do any keyword reservations for 2021.

(I might be able to draft that, if early March is fine)
I'd be in favor of that, @scottmcm
early match seems to suffice per the deadlines I laid out
if we move aggressively
Yeah, it felt like one where moving swiftly would be feasible. (Relatively few questions about it, I think.)
